column4: OK, I really need help.... I followed this guide to make a backup of my system http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?t=35087 Then I reinstalled in order to get rid of my windows partition. I am now trying to restore and I run the command tar xvpfz backup.tgz -C / and it goes for awhile and says tar: Skipping to next header then tar: Exiting with failure status due to previous errors
are you restoring your backup from a live environment?
Yes
instead of "-C /" you probably want the mounted root of your hdd, something like "-C /media/Ubuntudisk/"
Sorry... I'm not running off the cd I installed a new ubuntu and I'm running off the harddrive
you need to do the restore from a liveCD. and is the version of ubuntu you backed up the same as the one you installed?
Yes
good. in the future, just so you know, you can remove windows without reinstalling. you can just use Partition Editor to delete the windows partition and get grub to update its list
So I should boot the live cd?
By the way, I knew that but I wanted to expand my ubuntu partition as well so I had more space
yes. then do the restore with the -C pointing at a *mounted* copy of your hdd
OK, Thanks
How do I find the location of my Hard Drive when on the live cd
you click on Places at the top and click on on the name of your drive. then in a terminal you list /media with "ls /media" and the name of your disk should be in there
then you use "-C /media/ubuntudiskname"
Dammit, same error
are you using "sudo tar" ?
Yes I'm root
Tried again... Sam thing.
please copy and paste into a pastebin what you have in your terminal with the tar commands and the output
Can't I have no internet. I had to use the windows drivers to get the wireless card working. That's why I need to restore
no ethernet?
Not where the computer is
do you get any message saying something like "this doesn't look like a tar archive"?
No
The error is tar: Skipping to next header then tar: Exiting with failure status due to previous errors
eh well in that guide you're following it mentions that "exit delayed from previous errors" issue and says to ignore it
you could add the -v flag to tar and pipe it to a file for examination
otherwise if you don't notice any files you wanted are gone, then it might be okay to just figure the backup restore worked
Well it quits way too early.
So the command is sudo tar -v xvpfz Backup.tgz -C /media/.......
are there some files you need more than others? say the stuff in /home?
I backed up all of the root
i'm thinking of extracting it in parts though
Ok
I don't know if I need much/any of the stuff from /home
if you do "tar tf Backup.tgz | head", do the lines start with / ?
just running that command I get No file or directory
should run that in the directory you have the Backup.tgz
I did cd /media/... and I still get the error
where is your Backup.tgz?
On my hard drive in the root directory
(all without quotes) cd there, type "tar tf Backu" then hit tab
btw | is pipe, above the \ on US keyboard layouts.
after tab type "| head"
ah yeah that's good to know.
Any ideas?
tar xvpfz Backup.tgz --exclude=/media -C /media/ubuntudisk
xvpzf rather
didn't work :'(
what was the output?
tar: Skipping to next header and tar: Exiting with failure status due to previous errors
alright try this:  tar xvpzf Backup.tgz -C /media/ubuntudisk /home
same thing
is it a problem with the backup?
alright try this: sudo tar xpzf Backup.tgz -C /media/ubuntudisk /etc
we'll find out
with a space between /media/ubuntudick and /ect it said tar: skipping to next header and tar: /ect: Not found in archive and tar: exiting with failure status due to previous error
/etc not /ect
same thing
what is the output of "tar tvfz Backup.tgz" ?
tar: Skipping to next header tar: exiting with failure status due to previous errors
alright i'm putting together a command
make sure you're in the mounted root of your drive, the *same* dir as Backup.tgz
gunzip -c Backup.tgz | cpio -ivduH tar
type that exactly
Its going really fast and saying a lot of permission denied and malformed number
are you using sudo or a bash as root?
ctrl+c it and do "sudo su"
Thats better
sudo -i would also work
seem like it's working?
it got to it's usual spot then started spitting out malformed number
what's the usual spot?
like usr/share/ then something else
it's back to regular things now
I think it might be working !
wait for it to finish, then try booting into it and checking if what you wanted restored gets restored
btw in the future, it's better to use integrated backup tools rather than commands from a forum if one isn't experienced in the interworkings of tools like tar.
this is a better way to backup: https://help.ubuntu.com/community/BackupYourSystem
I tried that and it didn't seem to work for me
https://help.ubuntu.com/community/BackupYourSystem/SimpleBackupSuite
that's the program I used first and it didn't seem to even start backing up
but it's going alot further...
WTF? chinese characters?
heh no idea. it's your system :P
here's something you might want to use in the future: http://www.ubuntugeek.com/back-in-time-a-simple-backup-tool-for-ubuntu.html
welcome back
do you remember what the command was that you gave me? The comp just went to sleep and won't come back on. I'll write it down now...
here's something you might want to use in the future: http://www.ubuntugeek.com/back-in-time-a-simple-backup-tool-for-ubuntu.html
sudo -i        then   gunzip -c Backup.tgz | cpio -ivduH tar
thanks a bunch
bed time now g'night
